Award.AwardTitle: AF: Medium: Collaborative Research: Sparse Polynomials, Complexity, and Algorithms

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Solving equations quickly is what gets modern technology off the ground: Transmitting conversations between cellphones, sending data from space-craft back to earth, navigating aircraft, and making robots move correctly, all rely on solving equations quickly. In each setting, the equations have their own personality -- a special structure that we try to take advantage of, in order to find solutions more quickly. In this project, the principle investigators will study equations involving sparse polynomials -- polynomials that have few terms but very high degree.

But solving equations is more than just calculating quickly -- it also means understanding, and using, computational hardness. For example, classical results in Number Theory and Algebraic Geometry give us specially structured equations that, after centuries of research, still can not be solved quickly. These are the equations that are actually the most useful in Cryptography and complexity theory: Computational hardness can be used to secure sensitive data by forcing an adversary to spend a prohibitively large effort before successfully stealing anything. However, truly understanding hardness is subtle: Every day, codes and cryptosystems are broken because of a missed theoretical detail or a newly discovered backdoor.

The principal investigators on this project are world experts in Algebraic Geometry, Number Theory, Complexity Theory, and specially structured equations. They bring sophisticated new tools, never used before in Complexity Theory, in order to better classify what kinds of algebraic circuits define intractable equations. Their interdisciplinary approach is well-suited toward attracting mathematically talented students to theoretical Computer Science, Cryptography, and Number Theory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Arithmetic geometry is one of the central areas of number theory and lies
at the heart of new methods in cryptography and information security.
Complexity theory studies the hardness of computational problems, in order
to decide which algorithms are more practical, and which hard problems can
be applied toward information security. While it is easy to come up with
ad hoc ideas for encryption, using arithmetic geometry provides a framework
that provides much greater security. This is because arithmetic geometry
includes some of the deepest questions in modern mathematics, and is
continuously studied by some of the very best researchers in mathematics.

Our approach starts from the point of view of sparse polynomials. This means
that our results attempt to study the hardness of various questions regarding
a polynomial f, as a function of the number of monomial terms. The questions
we consider include, for instance, ``Does f have any roots?''
``How many roots does f have?'' ``How close are the roots to each other?''
Understanding the hardness of a computational problem as a function of
its input complexity is a central idea in theoretical computer science.

One example of how this kind of algebra can be useful for computer science
is via a recent result of Koiran: He showed that a precise enough bound
on the number of (integer) roots of structured polynomials implies a new
separation of complexity classes closely related to the famous P vs. NP
question. That such a seemingly simple question can have such deep implications is one of our motivations.

The outcomes of our work include introducing undergraduates to their
first research experiences, training graduate students to become
successful mathematicians, shaping the direction of future research
through active participation in conferences, and publishing in major
research journals. (Rojas is also PI on an REU at Texas A&M, where he mentors numerous undergrads, many from under-represented groups.) A full technical description of our work can be found easily within the research papers freely downloadable from the principal investigators' web pages.

Two toy examples of our work (which occupies over 13 research papers, most of which have already been published) are illustrated in Figures 1 and 2.

Figure 1 shows a tree structure underlying the problem of counting the
number of solutions of a degree 5 polynomial in the ring of integers
modulo 17^100: The tree structure has just 83 nodes, enabling the number
of roots to be computed in a fraction of a second. The best previous
algorithms would have taken time on the order of many years.

Figure 2 shows a plot (on log paper) of the maximal number of roots a
trinomial can have over a finite field, as a function of the (prime) number
of elements of the field. (A trinomial is just a polynomial with 3 terms,
and we assume our trinomials have any degree, but include a linear middle term.) In particular, the plot shows the results of a months-long super-computer calculation revealing that the maximal number of roots is logarithmic in the field cardinality. The best current bound (derived by our research group) is approximately the square root of the field cardinality. The sharper logarithmic bound, if true, would have important implications for the security of certain cryptosystems. The sharper bound would also imply a simpler approach to certain constructions in compressive sensing, thanks to recent work of Foucart and Rojas.
